text: Number Theory Fall 2009 Homework 12 Due: Wed. Dec. 2, start of class 10.4 Quadratic ﬁelds and their integers Exercise 10.6. Let d ∈ Z be a non-square. Show that F = Q( √d) has degree 2 over Q. Exercise 10.7. Check that OQ = Z. Exercise 10.8. Let d be squarefree, and α = a + b √d where a, b ∈ Q, i.e., α ∈ Q(√d). As usual α = a − b √d, and the norm is N (α) = αα. Deﬁne the trace of α to be tr(α) = α + α. Show the minimum polynomial for α is p(x) = x2 − tr(α)x + N (α). This formula may remind you of the formula characterisic polynomial for a 2 × 2 non-scalar matrix, where one replaces norm by determinant. In particular this means every α ∈ Q( √d) is in fact an algebraic number of degree 2. Moreover, it means the integers of Q(√d) are precisely the elements whose trace and norm is an integer. This is a more intuitive way of looking at what it means to be an algebraic integer of degree 2. Exercise 10.9. Check the trace (as deﬁned above) is a group homomorphism from (Q( √d), +) to (Q, +). In other words check (i) tr(α) ∈ Q for α ∈ Q(√d), and (ii) tr(α + β) = tr(α) + tr(β) for α, β ∈ Q( √d). 11.1 Revisiting Z Exercise 11.1. Check that I + J and IJ indeed deﬁne ideals. Exercise 11.2. Let m, n ∈ Z. Show (m) + (n) = (gcd(m, n)) and (m)(n) = (mn). (Cf. Exercise 11.1.1.) Exercise 11.3. Let R be a ring and α, β ∈ R. Show (α)|(β) (principal ideals) implies α|β (ele- ments). In particular if R = Z and m, n ∈ Z, then (m)|(n) ⇐⇒ m|n. (I combined Exercise 11.3 and 11.6 from the notes, since the proof is the same.) 11.2 Revisiting Z[ √−3] Exercise 11.4. Check that the ideal (2, 1 + √−3) in Z[ √−3] is not principal. (Use contradiction.) Reading It may also be a good idea to read over some of Chapter 11 from the text (or the notes) to help familiarize yourself with ideals. Also, it looks like we won’t get around to this in class, so over break why don’t you google “Fermat’s last theorem n=4.” There are several websites that explain the argument, which really isn’t so diﬃcult. 1
